chapter: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents with difficulty chewing and numbness on the right side of his jaw following a recent sports injury. Examination reveals weakened jaw clenching on the right and decreased sensation over the anterior cheek, but intact sensation in the lower lip. Which of the following nerves might be affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Anterior division of mandibular nerve Explanation: The presented scenario indicates a lesion of the anterior division of the Mandibular nerve , characterized by symptoms such as weakness of the jaw and reduced sensation in the anterior cheek, while sensation in the lower lip remains intact. Mandibular Nerve: It is the largest, mixed branch of the trigeminal nerve (nerve of the first branchial arch ). Course: A. Branches of the Main trunk: B. Branches of the Anterior division: C. Branches of the Posterior Division:
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: Which of the following cranial nerves does not receive motor fibers from the nucleus ambiguus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:D) Trigeminal nerve (V) Explanation: The trigeminal nerve does not receive fibers from the nucleus ambiguus; it is primarily sensory and motor for muscles of mastication, supplied by the trigeminal motor nucleus, not the nucleus ambiguus. Nucleus Ambiguus Location and Function: The nucleus ambiguus is a motor nucleus. It provides fibres to cranial nerves IX (Glossopharyngeal) , X (Vagus) , and the cranial root of XI (Accessory) nerve. (Option A, B, and C ruled out) Cranial Part: Supplies muscles of the palate, pharynx, and larynx via cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. Caudal Part: Sends fibres to the spinal root of the accessory nerve (XI) , supporting motor function. Innervation Source: Receives inputs from ipsilateral and contralateral motor cortices , ensuring coordinated motor control. Reference: Grey's Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Page 1464-e20 BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Page 56, 61
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman presents with unilateral facial pain and sensory loss on the left side of her face. Examination reveals that she cannot feel light touch, pain, or temperature on the left side, but her corneal reflex remains intact. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?

options.C: Lesion of right spinal trigeminal nucleus
options.D: Lesion of left spinal trigeminal nucleus

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Lesion of left spinal trigeminal nucleus Explanation : The patient's symptoms of unilateral facial pain and sensory loss (light touch, pain, and temperature) on the left side of her face, along with an intact corneal reflex, suggest a lesion affecting the sensory pathways of the trigeminal nerve. The spinal trigeminal nucleus transmits pain and temperature sensations from the face. A lesion of the spinal trigeminal nucleus on one side affects the ipsilateral (same side) face. The corneal reflex involves the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1) and the facial nerve (CN VII). Since this reflex is intact, the involvement is limited to the spinal trigeminal nucleus, sparing the pathways responsible for the corneal reflex. Nuclei of the trigeminal nerve: Nucleus Location Function Mesencephalic Nucleus Midbrain Proprioception (position sense) of muscles of mastication and jaw. A lesion here would affect the jaw-jerk reflex. Main Sensory Nucleus Pons Mediates tactile (light touch) and pressure sensations from the face. Spinal Trigeminal Nucleus Extends from the pons to the spinal cord. Handles pain and temperature sensations from the face. Motor Nucleus Pons Controls muscles involved in chewing (mastication).
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly distinguishes the role of the hypoglossal nerve from the olfactory nerve? via the thalamus. smell without synapsing in the thalamus.

options.A: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the muscles of the tongue, while the olfactory nerve mediates smell
options.B: The hypoglossal nerve is involved in motor control of the tongue, while the olfactory nerve mediates
options.C: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the tongue and is part of the olfactory pathway.
options.D: Both the hypoglossal and olfactory nerves are involved in taste and smell.

questions.explanation: olfactory nerve mediates smell without synapsing in the thalamus. Correct Answer: B) The hypoglossal nerve is involved in motor control of the tongue, while the olfactory nerve mediates smell without synapsing in the thalamus. Explanation: The hypoglossal nerve controls tongue movements, and the olfactory nerve processes smell without thalamic involvement. Hypoglossal Nerve and Olfactory Pathway Hypoglossal Nerve (Cranial Nerve XII): Supplies the muscles of the tongue . Belongs to the general somatic efferent column . Not involved in the olfactory pathway. (Option C and D ruled out) Olfactory Pathway (Cranial Nerve I): Belongs to the special visceral afferent column. Receptors and First Neuron: Bipolar olfactory cells in the nasal mucosa serve as receptors and first neurons. Second Neuron: Mitral and tufted cells in the olfactory bulb form the olfactory tract and reach the primary olfactory areas (e.g., periamygdaloid and prepiriform areas). Third Neuron: Located in the primary olfactory cortex, including the anterior perforated substance. Fourth Neuron: Fibres project to the secondary olfactory cortex in the entorhinal area and tertiary cortex in the orbitofrontal region. Pathway bypasses the thalamus and is solely sensory, unrelated to the hypoglossal nerve. (Option A ruled out) Reference: Grey's Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Page 1464-e26 BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Pages 63, 94
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 62-year-old patient presents with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Physical examination reveals a diminished gag reflex and weakened pharyngeal elevation during swallowing. Which of the following structures is not innervated by the affected nerve?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Palatopharyngeus Explanation: The affected nerve in the given scenario is Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial nerve IX). The Palatopharyngeus muscle is innervated by branches of the pharyngeal plexus from the vagus nerve CN (X). Glossopharyngeal Nerve: (Cranial Nerve IX) Mixed nerve , primarily responsible for sensory functions. Functional Components and Nuclei: Fibers Function Nucleus Special Visceral Efferent Supplies Stylopharyngeus muscle Nucleus Ambiguous General Visceral Efferent Secretomotor innervation to the Parotid gland Inferior Salivatory Nucleus. Special Visceral Afferent Taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue (including vallate papillae) Nucleus Tractus Solitarius. General Visceral Afferent Carry pain, touch, and temperature sensations from the pharynx, tonsils, soft palate, and posterior one-third of the tongue Dorsal Nucleus of the Vagus. General Somatic Afferent Carry proprioceptive sensations from the stylopharyngeus muscle and skin of the auricle. Spinal Nucleus of the Trigeminal nerve. Branches and their functions: Tympanic Branch (Jacobson’s Nerve): Enters the middle ear and forms the tympanic plexus , which gives: Lesser petrosal nerve : Carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion , supplying the parotid gland (Option C) Twigs to the tympanic cavity , auditory tube , and mastoid air cells . Carotid Nerve (Herring’s Nerve) : Supplies Carotid sinus and Carotid body (Option A) Pharyngeal Branch: Forms pharyngeal plexus on the middle constrictor muscle. Branch to Stylopharyngeus : Only motor branch, innervating Stylopharyngeus muscle (Option B) Tonsillar Branches : Sensory innervation to the mucous membrane of the tonsils, fauces, and palate. Lingual Branches : Provide taste and general sensory innervation to the posterior one-third of the tongue and vallate papillae .
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with difficulty swallowing and a hoarse voice after recent neck surgery. What structure does the vagus nerve primarily run between as it descends in the neck?

options.A: Internal carotid artery and external jugular vein
options.B: Internal jugular vein and common carotid artery
options.C: Subclavian artery and internal thoracic artery
options.D: External carotid artery and internal jugular vein

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Internal jugular vein and common carotid artery Explanation: The vagus nerve descends within the carotid sheath, positioned between the internal jugular vein (laterally) and the common carotid artery (medially). Injury or irritation to the vagus nerve can lead to symptoms like difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) and hoarseness due to its innervation of the laryngeal muscles and pharynx. Course and Relations of the Vagus Nerve: Origin : Originates from the lateral aspect of the medulla oblongata, lateral to the olivary nucleus. Intracranial course : Fibers run forward and laterally through the medullary reticular formation between the olivary nucleus and inferior cerebellar peduncle. Trunk formation : The rootlets converge to form a trunk that crosses the jugular tubercle alongside the glossopharyngeal and accessory nerves before reaching the jugular foramen. Cranial exit : The nerve exits the cranial cavity through the middle part of the jugular foramen, situated between the sigmoid and inferior petrosal sinuses. Neck descent : It descends within the carotid sheath, located between the internal jugular vein (laterally) and the internal/common carotid arteries (medially) . Thoracic entry : The right vagus crosses in front of the subclavian artery to reach the right trachea; the left vagus passes between the left common carotid and left subclavian arteries. Branches and Distribution: Meningeal Branch : Supplies the dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa. Auricular Branch (Arnold's Nerve) : Supplies skin around the external auditory meatus; can cause reflex coughing or vomiting when stimulated. Pharyngeal Branch : Contributes to the pharyngeal plexus and innervates most pharyngeal and soft palate muscles. Branches to Carotid body : Involved in baroreception. Superior Laryngeal Nerve : Divides into: External Laryngeal Nerve : Supplies the cricothyroid muscle. Internal Laryngeal Nerve : Supplies sensory innervation to the larynx above the vocal cords. Cervical Cardiac Branches : Provide parasympathetic fibers to the heart. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve : innervates all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except cricothyroid. Right: Loops around the right subclavian artery. Left: Loops under the arch of the aorta. Internal carotid artery and external jugular vein (Option A): Incorrect because the external jugular vein is superficial and not part of the carotid sheath. Subclavian artery and internal thoracic artery (Option C): Incorrect; recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the subclavian artery on the right , but the vagus nerve itself is higher up in the carotid sheath . External carotid artery and internal jugular vein (Option D): Incorrect; external carotid artery is anterior and branches out above the carotid bifurcation , not forming a sheath with the vagus.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 38-year-old female with down-out and intorsion of the eye presents with worsening night vision, occasional headaches, and mild dizziness. Examination shows ptosis and a larger, non-reactive left pupil. Which of the following structures is the parasympathetic component of the affected nerve?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Edinger-Westphal nucleus Explanation: The given scenario suggests the lesion of the parasympathetic component of the oculomotor nerve, which is the Edinger-Westphal nucleus. Oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) Type Motor Origin Midbrain (Oculomotor sulcus on the medial aspect of the cerebral peduncle). Course Components Oculomotor nucleus (somatic component) (Option B): General somatic efferent (GSE) fibres emerge from this site and supply - Superior division : Levator palpebrae superioris Superior rectus Inferior division : Medial rectus Inferior rectus Inferior oblique Edinger-Westphal nucleus (parasympathetic component) (Option A): General visceral efferent (GVE) fibres arise from this site and supply: Sphincter pupillae Ciliaris Note: The nerve fibers innervating the pupillary muscles are located superficially in the nerve trunk and pial blood vessels supply these fibers. The main trunk of the fibers is supplied by the vasa vasorum. Diabetic and hypertensive microangiopathy will affect the vasa vasorum and thus spare the pupillary fibers. Hence, pupil-sparing 3rd nerve lesions are seen with ischemic lesions such as diabetes, hypertension, or arteriosclerotic disease. Superior colliculus (Option C) of the midbrain serves as the origin for the tectospinal tract (oculomotor nerve originates at the same level). Axons from its neurons decussate at the dorsal tegmental decussation and mediate reflex movements of the head and neck in response to visual stimuli. Red nucleus (Option D): The rubrospinal tract originates from the red nucleus in the midbrain. Its fibres decussate at the ventral tegmental decussation and regulate the tone of limb flexor muscles by providing excitatory input to their motor neurons.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with facial asymmetry and difficulty smiling. Upon examination, the physician suspects a lesion affecting the facial nerve.Where does the facial nerve divide into its five terminal branches within the parotid gland?

options.B: Behind the neck of the mandible
options.C: Near the spine of the sphenoid

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Behind the neck of the mandible Explanation: The facial nerve divides into its five terminal branches (temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical) behind the neck of the mandible, within the parotid gland. Anatomical Landmark for Identification of the Facial Nerve Trunk Location of Exit: The facial nerve exits the skull through the stylomastoid foramen . (Option A ruled out) Proximity to Structures: Crosses the lateral side of the base of the styloid process . Enters the posteromedial surface of the parotid gland . In Relation to Parotid Gland: Within the parotid gland, it runs forward and crosses: The retromandibular vein . The external carotid artery . Division Point: Behind the neck of the mandible, the trunk divides into its five terminal branches : temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical. Nearby Landmarks: Stylomastoid foramen serves as a key entry/exit point for surgical or clinical identification. The nerve lies near the spine of the sphenoid after exiting the middle ear through the petrotympanic fissure. (Option C ruled out) Within the middle ear (Option D): The facial nerve passes through the middle ear but does not divide there. It exits the middle ear through the petrotympanic fissure before running toward the stylomastoid foramen and ultimately dividing behind the mandible.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 35-year-old female presents with sharp, shooting pain and numbness in her forehead, upper eyelid, upper face, upper lip, and part of her cheek after a recent car accident. She has a diminished corneal reflex on the right side. Which divisions of the trigeminal nerve are affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) V1, V2 Explanation: The scenario with sharp, shooting pain in the forehead, upper lip, and cheek, along with a loss of the corneal reflex, indicates that the V1 and V2 divisions of the trigeminal nerve are likely affected. Trigeminal nerve (5th cranial nerve): Has three divisions Ophthalmic division (V1) Maxillary division (V2) Mandibular division (V3) Type Sensory Sensory Mixed Course Branches Frontal Supratrochlear Supraorbital Nasociliary Branch to the ciliary ganglion 2–3 long ciliary nerves Posterior ethmoidal Infratrochlear Anterior ethmoidal Lacrimal: Branch to the upper eyelid and secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland. Infraorbital Zygomaticofacial Zygomaticotemporal Mental Buccal Auriculo-temporal Supply Forehead Upper eyelids Root of nose Tip of nose Frontal air sinus Scalp Lower eyelids Lateral sides of the nose Upper lip Cheek (upper part) Anterior part of the temporal region Lower lip Chin Lower teeth Lower part of the cheek Lateral side (Upper 2/3rd) of auricle, temporal region
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 60-year-old female presents with drooping of her left eyelid, double vision, and a dilated, fixed left pupil. She also reports difficulty focusing on close objects and some mild forward projection of her left eye. Neurological examination reveals that the left eye is turned downward and outward. A CT scan shows no evidence of mass lesions or hemorrhage.Which of the following is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Complete Oculomotor Nerve Palsy Explanation: The patient's symptoms, including ptosis (drooping eyelid), diplopia (double vision), dilated pupil with absent light reflex, lateral squint (due to unopposed action of lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles), and difficulty focusing on near objects (loss of accommodation), are classic signs of oculomotor nerve palsy. The absence of mass lesions or hemorrhage in the CT scan makes this diagnosis more likely than other options. Oculomotor Nerve Palsy and Associated Nerve Fibres Symptoms of Complete Oculomotor Nerve Palsy: Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle. Lateral Squint: Eyeball turns laterally due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Pupillary Dilatation: Due to paralysis of parasympathetic fibres to the sphincter pupillae muscle. Loss of Accommodation: Caused by paralysis of the ciliary muscles . Slight Proptosis: Forward projection of the eye. Diplopia: Double vision due to misalignment of the eyes. Absence of Pupillary Light Reflex: Affected eye does not respond to light. Causes and Associated Lesions: Weber’s Syndrome: Midbrain lesion causing contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy . Supranuclear Paralysis: Loss of conjugate eye movement due to higher center damage. Compression of the Oculomotor Nerve: Caused by extradural haematoma , affecting parasympathetic fibres first, resulting in pupil dilation with little response to light. Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral or superior cerebellar arteries may compress the nerve as it passes between these arteries. Trochlear Nerve Palsy (Option B) : Trochlear nerve palsy typically causes vertical diplopia and difficulty looking downward. It would not lead to the dilated pupil or the outward deviation of the eye seen in this patient. It also wouldn't cause ptosis or loss of accommodation. Abducens Nerve Palsy (Option C) : Abducens nerve palsy causes the eye to deviate inward due to loss of lateral rectus muscle function, not outward as in this patient. It does not typically result in pupil dilation or ptosis. Supranuclear Lesion (Option D) : Supranuclear lesions affect conjugate eye movements and may cause abnormal eye movements. But they would not typically cause the specific symptoms of pupil dilation, ptosis, and lateral squint seen in oculomotor nerve palsy.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: Identify the structure marked with the arrow and select which nerve root arises from it.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hypoglossal nerve Explanation: The olive, marked by the arrow, is located near the preolivary sulcus where the hypoglossal nerve rootlets emerge. Olive (Inferior Olivary Nucleus) Location and Structure: The olive is an oval elevation in the medulla , formed by the inferior olivary nucleus . Appears like a crumpled purse due to its grey matter. Located in the upper lateral region of the medulla. The principal olivary nucleus is C-shaped with a medial hilum . The medial and dorsal accessory olivary nuclei are near the olive. Function: Receives afferent fibres from the cerebral cortex , red nucleus , periaqueductal grey , and spinal cord . Sends efferent olivocerebellar fibres to the cerebellum, forming climbing fibres . Climbing fibres are mostly contralateral , with some fibres crossing bilaterally within the cerebellum. These fibres split into 7–10 branches , sending collaterals to the deep cerebellar nuclei before reaching the molecular layer of the cerebellum. Anatomy and Nerve Rootlets: The olive is bounded by the preolivary sulcus (ventrally) and retro-olivary sulcus (dorsally). Hypoglossal nerve rootlets emerge from the pre-olivary sulcus . Vestibular nerve rootlets emerge inferior to the inferior cerebellar peduncle . Glossopharyngeal , vagus , and accessory nerve rootlets emerge at the retro-olivary sulcus . Olivocerebellar fibres aggregate into the contralateral restiform body , a key part of the olivocerebellar tract. Abducens nerve (Option A) : The abducens nerve arises from the pons, not the medulla. Glossopharyngeal
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: Which of the following cranial nerves is not involved in the Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) pathway?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Trochlear nerve (IV) Explanation: The trochlear nerve is a General Somatic Efferent (GSE) nerve responsible for motor control of the superior oblique muscle and does not participate in the SVA pathway. Trochlear Nerve and Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) Column Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): Located in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus . Belongs to the General Somatic Efferent (GSE) column. Responsible for the movement of the superior oblique muscle of the eye. Not involved in the Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) column, as it lacks any sensory function for taste or olfaction. Special Visceral Afferent (SVA): Mediates taste and olfaction via the nucleus of tractus solitarius . Involves cranial nerves VII (Facial), IX (Glossopharyngeal), and X (Vagus) . (Option A,B,C ruled out) The trochlear nerve does not contribute to these sensory pathways. Reference: Grey's Anatomy, 42nd edition, Pages 391,1464-e12 BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th edition, Page 59
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei from ventral to dorsal in the brainstem? (SVA), Special Somatic Afferent (SSA). General Somatic Efferent (GSE). General Somatic Afferent (GSA). General Visceral Afferent (GVA).

options.A: General Visceral Efferent (GVE), General Visceral Afferent (GVA), Special Visceral Afferent
options.B: General Somatic Afferent (GSA), Special Somatic Afferent (SSA), General Visceral Efferent (GVE),
options.C: General Somatic Efferent (GSE), Special Visceral Efferent (SVE), General Visceral Efferent (GVE),
options.D: Special Visceral Afferent (SVA), Special Somatic Afferent (SSA), General Somatic Efferent (GSE),

questions.explanation: Visceral Afferent (SVA), Special Somatic Afferent (SSA). Correct Answer: A) General Visceral Efferent (GVE), General Visceral Afferent (GVA), Special Visceral Afferent (SVA), Special Somatic Afferent (SSA). Explanation: Functional Columns of Cranial Nerve Nuclei (Ventral to Dorsal Arrangement) Motor Columns (Basal Lamina, Medial Position): General Somatic Efferent (GSE): Supplies muscles derived from somites (e.g., eye and tongue muscles). Special Visceral Efferent (SVE): Supplies branchial apparatus-derived muscles (e.g., facial and pharyngeal muscles). General Visceral Efferent (GVE): Autonomic motor supply to viscera, vessels, and glands. Sensory Columns (Alar Lamina, Lateral Position): General Visceral Afferent (GVA): Sensory input from viscera. Special Visceral Afferent (SVA): Sensory input from taste and olfaction (branchial apparatus-related). General Somatic Afferent (GSA): Sensory input from skin and somatic structures. Special Somatic Afferent (SSA): Sensory input for special senses (e.g., vision, hearing, balance). The nuclei are organized into longitudinal columns in the brainstem. Motor nuclei are positioned medially , derived from the basal lamina . Sensory nuclei are positioned laterally , derived from the alar lamina . Pontine flexure influences the horizontal stretching of the neural tube, affecting this arrangement.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 54-year-old male presents with double vision and difficulty moving his left eye outward. Examination reveals the left eye is deviated medially with limited abduction. Which muscle is involved in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Left lateral rectus palsy Explanation: The scenario suggests damage to the left abducens nerve, which leads to left lateral rectus palsy and an ipsilateral medial squint , while the right side remains unaffected. Abducens Nerve (cranial nerve VI) Type Motor Origin Pons (lower border, opposite the pyramid of the medulla). Course Functional component General somatic efferent fibres : Arise from the abducent nucleu s in the pons and supply the lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball. General somatic afferent fibres carry proprioceptive sensations from the lateral rectus and terminate in the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Supply Lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball Clinical aspect Lesion or injury (elevated intracranial pressure) of the abducens nerve results in paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to: Inability to abduct the eye Diplopia (double vision) Convergent squint (due to the unopposed action of medial rectus) (Option B)
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: Below is an image of a transverse section of the lower pons, specifically at the level of the facial colliculus. Please identify the structures marked as "X" and "Y."
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Abducens nucleus and Facial nucleus Explanation: The abducens nucleus (X) is located medially and is responsible for innervating the lateral rectus muscle, which controls lateral eye movement. The facial nucleus (Y) is positioned more laterally and ventrally. It is responsible for the motor function of the muscles of facial expression. The fibres of the facial nerve loop around the abducens nucleus before exiting the brainstem, which forms the facial colliculus. Note: Abducens nerve palsy can be a false localizing sign. This occurs when lesions cause increased intracranial pressure, which stretches the sixth nerve.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 29-year-old male presents with a head tilt and double vision that worsens when looking down, especially while reading or using his phone. Examination shows a significant limitation in the left eye's downward movement, extorsion of the eyeball, and a noticeable right head tilt. At what site does the decussation of the affected nerve occur?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Superior medullary velum Explanation: The presented scenario is indicative of a trochlear nerve lesion , characterized by diplopia and a head tilt to the opposite side. Trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) Type Motor Origin Dorsal aspect of the midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus Special features The only cranial nerve which emerges on the dorsal aspect of the brain. The most slender nerve of all the cranial nerves. The smallest cranial nerve. Only cranial nerve whose nuclear fibres decussate before emerging on the surface of the brain. Nucleus receives only ipsilateral corticonuclear fibres. Phylogenetically, it is the nerve of the 3rd eye. Course Nuclei Trochlear nucleus is situated in the ventromedial part of the central grey matter in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus. Supply Superior oblique muscle of the eyeball. Clinical aspect Trochlear nerve lesions/injury causes paralysis of the superior oblique muscle, presenting clinically as: Extorsion of the eyeball and weakness of downward gaze (difficulty while going downstairs or reading the newspaper) Diplopia (double vision) occurs when the patient looks laterally and glances downward (there is a compensatory head tilt to the opposite side). Crus cerebri (Option A) is the section of the cerebral peduncle located anterolaterally to the substantia nigra. It contains vital descending tracts that link the cerebral cortex to the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, cranial nerve nuclei, and pontine nuclei and is not related to the trochlear nerve. Superior colliculus (Option B) receives inputs from the retina and other centres, sending outputs to the spinal cord via the tectospinal tract. It controls reflex movements of the eyes, head, and neck in response to visual stimuli. The oculomotor nerve originates at this level. Substantia nigra (Option D) is a crescent-shaped band of pigmented grey matter located between the tegmentum and the crus cerebri. It is a part of the basal ganglia, primarily involved in motor control through the dopaminergic system. It contains deeply pigmented nerve cells rich in melanin and iron.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 62-year-old male with diabetes arrives at the emergency department with sudden right-sided weakness and trouble speaking. His examination shows left-sided ptosis, the left eye in a "down and out" position, and right-sided paralysis of the lower face. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Weber’s syndrome Explanation: The presented case is diagnosed as Weber's Syndrome , which is characterized by right-sided hemiparesis, ight-sided paralysis of the lower face, left-sided ptosis and a "down and out" position of the left eye. This syndrome impacts the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) nucleus and corticospinal fibers , leading to the l oss of the medial lemniscus, red nucleus, superior cerebellar peduncle, and oculomotor nerve fibers. Characteristic features: Ipsilateral squint (pupil points downwards and laterally) due to injury to the oculomotor nerve. Contralateral hemiplegia due to involvement of corticospinal tract. Involvement of the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) in the midbrain causes Weber syndrome with vertical gaze palsy. Horner’s syndrome (Option A) is caused by damage to the cervical sympathetic trunk, which is characterized by: Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) Miosis (constriction of the pupil) Anhydrosis (loss of sweating on that side of the face) Enophthalmos (retraction of the eyeball) Loss of the ciliospinal reflex (pinching the skin on the nape of the neck does not cause pupil dilation, which typically occurs). Benedikt’s syndrome (Option B) is due to damage to most of the tegmentum of the midbrain, which is characterized by: Loss of proprioception due to the lesion of the medial lemniscus The pupil points downwards and laterally due to injury to the third nerve Tremors and twitching of opposite side due to damage to the red nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle. Parinaud’s syndrome (Option C) is due to a lesion of the superior colliculi (as shown in the above image), characterised by weakness of upward gaze and vertical nystagmus due to involvement of the superior colliculus.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 50-year-old patient experiences numbness in the area around the neck following a cervical block performed for neck surgery. Which of the following is not a branch of the cervical plexus?

options.B: Transverse Cutaneous Nerve of the Neck

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Phrenic Nerve Explanation: The Phrenic nerve arises primarily from the cervical spinal roots C3, C4, and C5 & its primary function is to provide motor innervation to the diaphragm, essential for breathing. Cervical Plexus: Formed by the ventral rami of the upper four cervical nerves (C1-C4) The Four roots interconnect to form three loops. Position and Relations: Posteriorly : It is related to muscles arising from the posterior tubercles of the transverse processes, including the levator scapulae and scalenus medius. Anteriorly : It is associated with the prevertebral fascia, the internal jugular vein, and the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Branches: Superficial (Cutaneous) Branches: Lesser Occipital (C2) Great Auricular (C2, C3) Transverse Cutaneous Nerve of the Neck (C2, C3) Supraclavicular Nerves (C3, C4) Deep Branches : Communicating Branches : A branch from C1 joins the hypoglossal nerve, supplying the thyrohyoid and geniohyoid muscles directly & superior belly of the omohyoid via ansa cervicalis. Branches from C2 and C3 supply the sternocleidomastoid, while branches from C3 and C4 s upply the trapezius, communicating with the accessory nerve.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient presents with difficulty swallowing and changes in voice quality. Upon examination, the physician suspects a neurological issue affecting the muscles of the larynx and pharynx. Which nucleus is responsible for the motor innervation of these muscles?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Nucleus ambiguus Explanation: The nucleus ambiguus is the primary nucleus that provides motor innervation to the muscles of the larynx and pharynx via the vagus nerve. Vagus Nerve (Cranial Nerve X) This mixed nerve is primarily motor in function and the longest of the cranial nerves. Carry most of the parasympathetic output from the cranial region, including fibers from the cranial part of the accessory nerve. Functional Components and Nuclei: Functional Column Function Nucleus Special Visceral Efferent Supply muscles of the palate, pharynx, and larynx Nucleus Ambiguus General Visceral Efferent Parasympathetic innervation to the heart, bronchial tree, and GIT Dorsal Nucleus of the Vagus (Option A) Special Visceral Afferent Taste sensations from the posterior part of the tongue and epiglottis Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (Option C) General Visceral Afferent Convey sensations from the mucous membranes of the pharynx, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and thoracic/abdominal viscera Nucleus Tractus Solitarius & Dorsal Nucleus of Vagus General Somatic Afferent Carry sensations from the skin of the Auricle Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve (Option D)
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient experiences redness and sweating in the right cheek while eating. Which of the following components is directly involved in the aberrant nerve regeneration causing these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Auriculotemporal postganglionic fibers Explanation: The scenario indicates Frey's syndrome , which results from the aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal postganglionic fibres following parotid surgery. When these nerves are severed, the regenerating secretomotor fibres can aberrantly grow into the endoneural sheaths of fibres that supply cutaneous receptors for pain, touch, and temperature, as well as sympathetic fibres that innervate sweat glands and blood vessels. As a result, a stimulus meant for salivation can trigger: Gustatory Sweating : When eating, the affected cheek (parotid region) may become red, hot, and painful, accompanied by beads of perspiration. Cutaneous Hyperesthesia : While shaving, the area in front of the ear may exhibit heightened sensitivity. Jacobson's nerve (Option A) also known as the tympanic nerve, is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve . It carries preganglionic fibers that synapse in the otic ganglion and involved in the parasympathetic supply of the parotid. Reference: Vishram Singh's Textbook of Anatomy, 2nd Edition, Page 116
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty swallowing and loss of taste sensation from the posterior third of his tongue. On examination, there is a loss of the gag reflex on the right side. Further tests reveal decreased salivary secretion from the parotid gland. Given the clinical findings, which of the following structures is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Otic ganglion Explanation : The patient's symptoms suggest a lesion of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) , which provides sensory innervation to the posterior third of the tongue and contributes to the gag reflex. Glossopharyngeal nerve Category Details Origin Arises from the brainstem. Nuclei involved: Nucleus ambiguus: Motor fibres. Inferior salivatory nucleus: Parasympathetic fibers. Pathway/Exit Travels between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein. Exits the skull via the jugular foramen. Course Parasympathetic fibres travel via the lesser petrosal nerve. Synapse in the otic ganglion. Postganglionic fibres from the otic ganglion innervate the parotid gland. Motor Supply Innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle. Function: Elevates the pharynx during swallowing. Sensory Supply Sensory innervation to the posterior third of the tongue (taste and general sensation). Sensory innervation to the pharynx (necessary for the gag reflex). Parasympathetic Supply Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland. Function: Salivation from the parotid gland. The submandibular ganglion (Option B) is part of the parasympathetic nervous system and is associated with the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). Postganglionic fibres innervate the submandibular and sublingual glands, controlling their salivary secretion. Ciliary ganglion (Option C) is a parasympathetic ganglion associated with the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). It controls parasympathetic innervation to the eye, particularly the sphincter pupillae muscle (pupil constriction) and ciliary muscles (lens accommodation for near vision). Pterygopalatine ganglion (Option D) is also part of the parasympathetic nervous system but is associated with the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). It controls parasympathetic innervation to the lacrimal gland and the mucous membranes of the nasal cavity, palate, and pharynx.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with difficulty in smiling and closing eyelids on the right side. The patient does not have any history of recent trauma or infections. The image below shows the patient's face. Sensory function, including taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and sensation to light touch, appears intact. Which nerve column is primarily responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) Explanation : The patient’s image reveals weakness of the facial muscles on one side of the face. Based on the clinical presentation and the image Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) is most likely to be affected. The muscles of facial expression, originating from the second branchial arch , are innervated by the facial nerve, with the SVE component arising from the facial nucleus in the brainstem. The special visceral efferent (SVE) column innervates muscles derived from the branchial arches. Nerve Column Nucleus Origin Function Special Visceral Afferent Nucleus Solitarius Carries taste sensations from
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman presents with excessive tearing while eating, which started a few months ago. Upon further questioning, she recalls having facial nerve palsy about a year ago, which has since improved. Based on this presentation, at what level of the facial nerve pathway did the injury most likely occur?

options.A: At the level of the geniculate ganglion
options.B: At the level of the chorda tympani
options.D: At the level of the greater petrosal nerve

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) At the level of the geniculate ganglion Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests Bogorad syndrome , also known as Crocodile tears syndrome , occurring due to the misdirection of parasympathetic fibres that regenerate after facial nerve injury. These fibres, which originally control salivation, are misdirected to the lacrimal gland, leading to involuntary tear production during eating. The injury that leads to this phenomenon typically occurs around the geniculate ganglion , where the parasympathetic fibers for both salivation and lacrimation are present. Damage here can lead to a mix of motor and sensory dysfunction, including taste disturbances and autonomic dysfunction. A- Suprageniculate lesions B- Suprastapedial lesions C- Infrastapedial lesions D- Infrachordal lesions Course of Facial Nerve Segment Description Clinical Significance (Topodiagnostic tests help in determining the location of facial nerve lesion) Intracranial (Cisternal) Emerges from the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction , medial to CN VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve). Lesions can cause facial weakness or paralysis. Intratemporal Meatal Segment It enters the internal acoustic meatus with CN VII I and the nervus intermedius. Vulnerable to compression in acoustic neuromas. Labyrinthine Segment ( Most common site for facial nerve palsy.) Extends from the internal acoustic meatus to the geniculate ganglion; limited blood supply. Damage can affect taste and hearing. Tympanic Segment Runs horizontally through the middle ear cavity above the oval window and stapes. Injury in this segment may lead to altered middle ear function and hearing. Mastoid Segment Longest segment; descends vertically through the mastoid bone, giving off branches like the nerve to stapedius and chorda tympani (anterior 2/3 tongue ) Injury can lead to facial nerve dysfunction, including Bell's palsy. Extratemporal Stylomastoid Foramen It exits the skull and enters the parotid gland. Damage here leads to facial muscle weakness but spares glands and taste. Parotid gland Divides into temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical branches to innervate facial muscles. The nerve passes through but does not innervate the parotid. Facial nerve injury during parotid surgery causes facial paralysis. Topodiagnostic tests Key points Schirmer test Decreased lacrimation indicates a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion. Stapedial reflex It is lost in lesions above the nerve to stapedius. Taste test Impairment of taste indicates a lesion above the chorda tympani. Submandibular salivary flow test Decreased salivation shows injury above the chorda tympani.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with difficulty chewing and pain near his temporomandibular joint (TMJ) after sustaining blunt trauma to the side of his face. Upon examination, there is tenderness over the ramus of the mandible. Which muscle is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Masseter Explanation: Masseter covers the ramus of the mandible, making it most likely to be affected by trauma to the side of the face, as described in the scenario. Its primary action is elevating the mandible , which is essential for biting and chewing. Anatomy of the mandible: The largest and strongest bone in the face. Parts of the Mandible: Body: Horizontal portion of the mandible. Alveolar process : Holds the lower teeth. Mental protuberance (chin) and mental foramen (allows passage of nerves and vessels). Mylohyoid line : For muscle attachment. Rami: Vertical portions on each side. Coronoid process : Attachment for the temporalis muscle . Condylar process : Forms the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) by articulating with the temporal bone. Mandibular Canal: Runs inside the mandible from the mandibular foramen to the mental foramen . Houses the inferior alveolar nerve and vessels supplying the lower teeth. Muscles of mandible Muscle Location Action Nerve Supply Masseter Covers the ramus of the mandible Elevates the mandible for biting and chewing Mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) Temporalis Attached to the coronoid process Elevates and retracts the mandible Lateral Pterygoid Located in the infratemporal fossa Protracts and depresses the mandible and moves it laterally. Medial Pterygoid It runs parallel to the masseter on the inner side of the ramus of mandible. Elevates and assists in protrusion of the mandible
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 34-year-old male presents with difficulty opening his mouth following a jaw injury. Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for opening the mouth?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Lateral pterygoid Explanation: The scenario describes trauma to the muscles responsible for depressing the jaw and opening the mouth, particularly the lateral pterygoid muscle. Muscles of mastication They are responsible for moving the mandible at the temporomandibular joints during the process of chewing. They are divided into: Principal muscles Accessory muscles Temporalis Masseter Lateral pterygoid Medial pterygoid Digastric Buccinator Mylohyoid Geniohyoid. Characteristic features: Situated in or around the infratemporal fossa and originate from the mesoderm of the first pharyngeal arch. They attach to the ramus of the mandible and are innervated by the mandibular nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve. Principal muscles of mastication Origin Insertion Nerve supply Action Masseter (Option A) Superficial layer (largest): Zygomatic arch (anterior 2/3rds of the lower border) and adjoining zygomatic process. Middle layer: Zygomatic arch (lower border of posterior 1/3rd). Deep layer: Zygomatic arch (deep) surface. Superficial layer: Ramus of the mandible (lower part of lateral surface). Middle layer: Ramus of mandible (central part). Deep layer: Ramus of the mandible (rest of the part) Masseteric nerve ( Anterior division of mandibular nerve) Elevates the mandible (close the mouth). Protrusion Temporalis (Option B) Temporal fossa (excluding zygomatic bone) Temporal fascia Coronoid process Ramus of mandible (anterior border). Deep temporal nerves ( Anterior division of mandibular nerve) Elevates mandible (close the mouth) Side-to-side (grinding) movement Retraction of mandible Lateral pterygoid (Option D) Upper head (smaller): Infratemporal surface and crest of greater wing (sphenoid bone) Lower head (larger): lateral pterygoid plate (lateral surface) Pterygoid fovea (neck of mandible) Articular disc (anterior margin) and capsule of temporomandibular joint A branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve Depresses mandible (open the mouth) Protrusion Turns chin to the opposite side (right lateral pterygoid turns chin to left) Medial pterygoid (Option C) Superficial head: tuberosity of maxilla and adjoining bone Deep head: lateral pterygoid plate (medial surface) and adjoining surface of palatine bone Angle (rough area on the medial surface) and adjoining ramus of the mandible. Nerve to medial pterygoid ( main trunk of the mandibular nerve) Elevates the mandible (close the mouth) Protrusion Grinding movement
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 48-year-old female with diabetes presents with severe, sharp right-sided facial pain triggered by light touch, along with numbness and tingling. Examination shows hyperesthesia and decreased sensation on the right side. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Spinal nucleus Explanation: The given scenario suggests a lesion of the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. The trigeminal nerve is associated with four nuclei (1 motor and three sensory). Nuclear columns of Trigeminal nerve ( Extends throughout the brainstem) General somatic afferent column : Has three nuclei Spinal nucleus of Vth nerve (Option A) Principal sensory nucleus of Vth nerve (Option D) Mesencephalic nucleus (Option C) Fibers conveying pain and temperature sensations from the majority of the facial area synapse at this location. Fibers transmitting touch and pressure sensations synapse in this nucleus This nucleus extends into the midbrain and receives proprioceptive impulses from the muscles of mastication, the temporomandibular joint, and the teeth. Special visceral efferent column: Motor nucleus of the Vth nerve (Option B) These fibres supply the muscles derived from the first pharyngeal arch, namely the muscles of mastication, the mylohyoid, the anterior belly of the digastric, the tensor palatini and the tensor tympani.
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with sudden numbness, tingling, heaviness, dull pain, and heightened sensitivity on the right side of her face. Examination shows reduced sensation in the right maxillary and mandibular areas, with intact motor function and no other deficits. From which location does the affected cranial nerve emerge?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pons Explanation: The presented scenario suggests a lesion at the sensory root of the trigeminal nerve, which originates from the pons. Trigeminal nerve (Cranial nerve V) The largest and thickest mixed nerve, containing both sensory and motor components. It is associated with four nuclei (1 motor and 3 sensory) and three primary divisions as: Ophthalmic division Maxillary division Mandibular division Course: Midbrain (Option A) is the origin of cranial nerves III (oculomotor nerve) and IV (trochlear). Cerebrum (Option B) is the origin of cranial nerves I (Olfactory nerve) and II (optic nerve). Medulla oblongata (Option D) is the origin of cranial nerves IX (glossopharyngeal nerve), X (vagus nerve), XI (accessory nerve) , and XII (hypoglossal nerve).
questions.chapter_heading: Head And Neck-Cranial Nerves And Cervical Plexus
